qas.question: When did the word emotion enter the English language?
From what French word is emotion derived?
What does émouvoir mean in English?
Prior to the introduction of the word emotion, what word was used in its place?
Along with anxiety, what is an example of directionless emotion?
When did the word emotion leave the English language?
From what English word is emotion derived?
What does émouvoir mean in Italian?
Prior to the introduction of the word emotion, what word wasn't used in its place?
Along with anxiety, what is not an example of directionless emotion?

context: The word "emotion" dates back to <a0_0><b5_0>1579<b5_0/><a0_0/>, when it was adapted from the French word <a1_0><b6_0>émouvoir<b6_0/><a1_0/>, which means "<a2_0><b7_0>to stir up<b7_0/><a2_0/>". The term emotion was introduced into academic discussion to replace <a3_0><b8_0>passion<b8_0/><a3_0/>. According to one dictionary, the earliest precursors of the word likely dates back to the very origins of language. The modern word emotion is heterogeneous In some uses of the word, emotions are intense feelings that are directed at someone or something. On the other hand, emotion can be used to refer to states that are mild (as in annoyed or content) and to states that are not directed at anything (as in anxiety and <a4_0><b9_0>depression<b9_0/><a4_0/>). One line of research thus looks at the meaning of the word emotion in everyday language and this usage is rather different from that in academic discourse. Another line of research asks about languages other than English, and one interesting finding is that many languages have a similar but not identical term
